Award.AwardTitle: RCN: Synthesizing Deep Time and Recent Community Ecology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the structure, function, and dynamics of ecosystems is a central goal of ecological research. Paleo-biologists are engaged in parallel efforts to reconstruct past ecological communities using associations of fossil plants and animals. Modern ecology knows a lot about how the individual components of ecological systems operate in the present day, but considerably less about the linkages that hold together communities and ecosystems over long periods of time. Paleo-ecological studies in deep time (from thousands of years to several hundred million years ago) can reveal how communities shift over evolutionary time and how they respond to major environmental changes. This project will establish a Research Coordination Network to bring together ecologists and paleo-biologists in an effort to bridge the gap between ecology and paleoecology and apply modern ecological theory to gain in-depth understanding of land-based faunas and floras over the past 400 million years. The network resources and expertise will focus on the following central question: What are the patterns and causal processes of animal and plant community assembly and disassembly over geological time and up to the present-day? This project will generate new perspectives on change in the planet's ecosystems before human impact, allow us to compare what is happening now, and give us some ideas about what may happen in the future.

This Research Coordination Network will produce a more comprehensive model for community assembly and disassembly that uses both neo- and paleo-ecological data and insights. This project will also produce a new synthetic book, Foundations of Paleoecology, which will integrate ecological theory with the paleo-biology record, and a public database of ecological communities of different land plants and animals over different scales of space and time. Additional broader impacts from this network include research experience and training of undergraduates and graduate students, and outreach to the general public through the new National Museum of Natural History, Deep Time exhibit and through games and teacher manuals to promote the teaching of linkages between ecology and paleoecology in public schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This grant supported the development of a collaborative interdisciplinary and international network (with members from the United States, Australia, Canada, and Europe) that was successful in fostering novel approaches to research questions about natural land-based communities and how they change over geological time. A key finding of this group is that there has been a fundamental change in the co-occurrence structure of plant and animal communities in the Holocene, reversing a pattern that was evident and stable for the prior 300 ma. For mammals, this change occurred because of a lessening in the importance of biotic interactions following the end-Pleistocene megafaunal extinction. We also find that as a result of these changes, mammal communities show significant homogenization beginning in the Holocene. In addition, we developed a framework for understanding how habitat characteristics influence co-occurrence patterns. Using this framework, we find that specific species associations are ephemeral and that for pollen, the influence of the environment on co-occurrence fluctuated through time. We also find that the role of species traits has changed through time. For mammals, body size played an important role in species co-occurrence prior to the modern era (post-industrial revolution), but not after. This is consistent with the finding that mammals have shifted their climatic niches in response to human expansion after the industrial revolution. We summarized the ways in which a deep time perspective can enhance our understanding of biotic interactions in a review article. Research products and measures of success from the ETE RCN include: 1) the construction of a global database of ecological communities over the last 300 million years developed as an R package ETERnity; 2) 93 talks at national and international meetings; 3) 25 published papers, including several in Nature and Science, and popular press coverage in a variety of international radio and print venues. 

 

Broader Impacts: Our broader impacts focused on the training of graduate students and postdocs, and interaction and outreach to the public about the history of life and the findings of the ETE RCN. This RCN resulted in the training of 10 graduate students and postdocs, 4 of whom were underrepresented minorities. Additional broader impacts include: 1) a Foundations of Paleoecology volume published by the University of Chicago Press; 2) symposia at GSA and SVP, 3) the translation of the ETE game Evolve or Perish into six languages, (Spanish, Catalan, Italian, Portuguese and Dutch, with French in progress), and the dissemination of the game to 3000+ people through outreach events at UNL and the ETE website, 4) incorporation of ETE findings into the new NMNH Deep Time exhibit, 5) an ETE led R-course; 6) training of K-12 teachers through the NMNH teaching workshop series, and 7) 14 public talks to a variety of groups including a symposium on ETE research to approximately 100 people in March 2017.
